new_works.title: Religion and the Limits of Modern Rationalism
new_works.description: Essay analyzing William James, Rudolph Otto, and Mircea Eliade's views on religion, arguing they actually describe pre-civilizational animistic spiritualism rather than institutional religion, and that rationalism is an extension rather than rejection of spiritualism.

new_works.title: Does Possible World Semantics Turn All Propositions into Necessary Ones?
new_works.description: Comprehensive systematic critique of Possible World Semantics (PWS), arguing it faces an inescapable dilemma between vicious circularity and superfluity, and that modality consists in structural properties of propositions rather than truth across possible worlds.

positions_summary.modal_logic: MODAL-001 through MODAL-024 (23 positions, excluding some not extracted)

notable_features.most_systematic: WORK-031 presents the most comprehensive and rigorous single-work critique in the database
cross_work_themes: Critique of reductionism in both works
Recognition of primitive concepts that resist analysis
Integration of historical-material conditions with philosophy

integration_notes: These 35 positions should be integrated into the appropriate domain sections of the master database. The Possible Worlds paper introduces a major new domain (Modal Logic) with 23 positions representing the most systematic single-work contribution yet. Update metadata to reflect version 19.0, 31 works analyzed, 684 total positions, 6.0% completion of ~518 total works.

key_arguments.WORK-030: Contemporary fundamentalism and atheism are psychologically similar forms of reactivity; James/Otto/Eliade misidentified animistic spiritualism as institutional religion; rationalism extends rather than rejects spiritualism; writing and material conditions create rationalist consciousness.
key_arguments.WORK-031: PWS makes all true propositions necessary (modal collapse); PWS requires literal worlds but faces insurmountable circularity problems; attempts to identify worlds with sets fail; counterpart theory cannot succeed; modality consists in structural properties of propositions, not truth across worlds; PWS faces an inescapable dilemma: circularity or superfluity.

recommended_queries: What is Kuczynski's critique of possible world semantics?
How does Kuczynski distinguish genuine spiritualism from contemporary religion?
What does Kuczynski say about the relationship between rationalism and spiritualism?
What are the circularity problems for modal realism?
How does material history shape consciousness according to Kuczynski?
What is Kuczynski's structural theory of modality?
Why does Kuczynski think contemporary atheism and fundamentalism are similar?
What did James, Otto, and Eliade actually describe in their religious phenomenology?
